text:
The following content is
provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help
MIT Open OpenCourseWare

continue to offer high quality
educational resources for free. To make a donation or
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT Open OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

BUS LEONARD: All right,
thanks, everybody for coming, my name is Bus Leonard. CARTER: I'm Carter. BRIANNA: I'm Brianna.

BUS LEONARD: And Rosser
is not here right now. And our team lead is Ken. And we're working on OJ sealer
for a community in Nicaragua.

We were partnered with
the NGO AsoFenix, which is a organization that does a
rural sustainable development

projects with multiple
communities in Nicaragua. And they do projects
that promote

clean water, electricity,
income generation, also educational projects that
help the community be healthy.

So our project centers around
the community El Roblar that we visited while
we were down there.

And they have a large orange
harvest crop that they get.

And there's no market for the
oranges during the harvest season, because everybody's
harvesting oranges.

So the idea is to
create a way for them to sell the oranges or a
product from the oranges

in the offseason
to generate income. And they were introduced
a pasteurization process

to preserve the orange
juice by AsoFenix and through the
University of Managua.

So that process is in place. And we are trying to
develop a way for them to seal a plastic bag in
order to preserve the juice.

And this is actually
stemming off of a project that was started
during last year's D-Lab Energy class.

And you see that project
picture at the bottom here. And our specifications
that we want

to achieve with our
project is to have it-- the device be able to run
off 120 volts of AC current

and while-- and
the seal should be done while removing
the air from the bag. So there's no air in the bag to
prevent spoiling of the juice

after it's sealed,
before it's sold. And we also want to
create and maintain

the durable, user friendly
interface that was-- beginning last year with
last year's project.

BRIANNA: So this is a bigger
picture of last year's project. And it sealed bags
nicely and all, but there's several
areas that we

feel need improving on before
it can actually really be used. The first one is
the power supply.

Between last year and this year,
the community we're working in

got rid of all their 12
volt batteries like that because they got a
micro hydro grid.

And so now they're
running on 120 AC. So we need to make it actually
be able to run on the power that they have.

We mentioned removing all
the air from the bags. The preservation process
isn't very strong.

So it's a key part of making
sure the orange juice stays good. The wide flat surface that
they're sealing on here

makes it very, very
difficult to do that. So we wanted to
improve that as well.

And then when we talk
about comfort in using it,

the light that indicated
whether something is hot or not

was right about here. And when you would use
it from the other side, it was very difficult to see.

There's a latch that's
really difficult to open.

And trying to get the bags
to get all the air out, because of the
wide flat surface, was also very difficult.

And the control-- the
timing circuit there, the used an out of the
box timing circuit.

Mainly, I think, because of
limited time that cost $26.

So we're also designing a
simplified timing circuit

built out of just components
that is only going to be a couple of dollars.

CARTER: So we wanted to
first go into experimentation and see what needed to be done
to get a good seal on a bag.

So we first started off
with what type of plastic do we need. We basically tested-- we got
some plastic from Nicaragua

and we brought it back. And it turned out to
be 25/1000 of an inch. So we're testing with 25/1000 of
an inch and 45/1000 of an inch

because there's
various plastics there. And so we wanted to test with
multiple types of plastic

to accommodate that. In addition to that, we wanted
to see what temperature was needed to fully seal plastic.

So we use the standard impulse--
or the industry standard, which is the impulse
sealer to seal a bag.

And we used a thermocouple
to determine the temperature. We got a temperature
of about 195 Celsius.

And you can see, gets
a good seal like this. Let me pass this
around if you want.

The water should be
orange juice, but-- yeah, so we got 195 Celsius.

That's the temperature
we need to hit. And in addition to
the temperature,

another factor is
pressure, how much force do you need to put
down on a nichrome wire to get a good seal.

So we use a force plate
sensor and pushed down on it. We got about 56 newtons,
which translates

to about 169 kilopascals
on the nichrome wire. And you could see
over here with--

if you don't apply
enough pressure, you get a perforated line,
where there's seals--

there's a lot of gaps
in between the seals. So this is not a good
seal, because there wasn't enough pressure,
although the time was perfect.

For this, with a
6 kilogram weight, you got a good, solid
seal on the bag.
Everything looks good. Water did not leak. And that is ideal.

In terms of timing,
we also want to make sure you apply the right amount
of time, or else it melts, the plastic will
melt. So what we

did was we had a
standard weights, we applied it to our rig and
tested with constant voltage,

different timing-- so we ran the device for
a certain amount of time

and then increased it slowly. So as you can see, as
we increased more time, this was enough-- this
wasn't enough pressure,

because you see the dimples. But you can see over time, that
is a very small seal to one that's melted.

And so with various weights,
and various voltages, and varying the time,
we got figured out

exactly what we need. So in terms of
power and voltage, I'll pass it off to Brianna.

BRIANNA: So before I get into
our different tests of power voltage, I notice that it says
5 volts, 10 volts, 12 volts,

but we were talking
about 120 volts AC. This is because we decided that
the best way to run something

off the wall power is actually
just to buy an adapter and plug it in and
convert it to 12 volts DC.

Running something off the
wall makes it very difficult to have our timing circuit work. We'd probably have to
rectify that into DC anyway.

120 volts with our nichrome
is like a 4 ohm resistor. We'd have to add either more
resistors that would do nothing

for the heating and be
expensive because they'd have to be big power resistors
or lots more nichrome

wire, which would,
again, be expensive. If we built our own adapter,
the price came out to just about

the same as what 12 volt 3, 4
amp adapters are selling for. And it would be more complicated
and harder to replace.

So it turns out that the
best solution to running it off the wall is just to
buy an adapter running off the 12 volts anyways.

So we did tests with
power and voltage-- power controlled
by what voltage we

were putting across a
resistor and the time that we left it on for.

These are just a couple
of samples there. See at 5 volts, even when we
were doing it for a minute, we didn't get hot enough
to melt the bag at all.

I know the pictures aren't
really great, but bear with us. At 10 volts, we had a good
seal in just 20 seconds.

And at 12 volts, by the
time it was 14 seconds,

we were already
sealing it too much. So this was giving
us a good idea

of our trade-offs between
how much power we're using, what range of powers
and times we can use.

I think we did get a good
seal at 12 volts at about 8 or 10 seconds.

But didn't really have a-- all visible picture
of that to show you.

CARTER: So that was the
experimentation that we did. And we wanted to use these
results into our design.

So when we designed
our product, we wanted to take two things
in the mind, functionality and usability.

Thing about functionality
is we want the users to be looking down on the product. So they can use it on a table.

And they also want
a nice latch system. So as you can see over here,
we have an angled product.

And since the angle, you can
look down on it, use it easily. I should be taller. But yeah, and with
this angled plane,

you can have a bag
hanging down as such. So that the liquid
will be in the bag

and that you can get a
good airtight seal here. BUS LEONARD: And
then another bonus is that the excess juice, we're
sealing through juice in order

to get an airtight seal. The extra juice, you
can just let run off after you make the seal.

And you can have a
pot sitting right here to catch the excess juice. So that's another-- and there's
springs in this arm that

allow you, once
you have-- once we have a latch system
that will keep the same force for every seal.

So you'll know that
you have enough force. And that given the
time and circuit, it'll run for the
same amount of time.

So the seals will
all be the same. And then more on
the latch system.

The springs also
provide some give that will allow this to
compress a little bit more

than the necessary
force for a seal. So we can just have
a simple rotating

thing out of sheet
metal, something that's readily available in Nicaragua.

And then you can slide it
over, like the picture. And then when you want it
off, you can press down. Slide it back up,
you're ready to go.

CARTER: We got some future
things that we need to work on. One thing would be
combining the ergonomics,

the usability of this
product, in addition to the functionality. We were doing a sample test on
a-- basically just two pieces

of wood testing,
putting weight on top. And so we need to add nichrome
wire onto the base of this

to seal bags with this design. In addition to that, we need
to finalize the circuitry

and design a housing
device for the electronics that we would be
placing on the side.

In addition to that, once
we have this completed, basically just get
users to test this, make sure it's intuitive, easy
to use, and a great product

overall. We'd like to thank
Ken, Amy, Amit, D-Lab

overall, and our community
partner AsoFenix. Are there any questions?

AUDIENCE: Right now,
are you testing that by sealing through water? CARTER: Yes. AUDIENCE: Can you
seal through pulp?

BUS LEONARD: That's
a good question. CARTER: We have
yet to test that. AUDIENCE: It's probably time
to buy some orange juice.

PROFESSOR: Yeah,
I would buy the-- AUDIENCE: The super
extra pulpy version,

throw some sticks
and rocks into it. PROFESSOR: And at one point,
it would be worth it to test,

like actually squeeze
your own juice, it's not that hard
to make a bit.

AUDIENCE: How
important is the latch? Why can't you just hold it?

BUS LEONARD: We wanted
to be able to, I guess, be easily used by
one person, ideally.

So if they-- we're not
sure that this there

could be cases of
filling like liter bags, or two liter bags of juice
if they're selling it to restaurants for kind of like
wholesale, like to restaurants.

This force pressing down might
not be enough to hold the bag. So they might need to be holding
the bag, pressing a button,

so you want you want to
be able to do one thing at a time with your free hand. CARTER: In addition
to that, you also want

to have a consent
force for each seal. So there can be variable forces
if you push harder or less

than each time. BRIANNA: I'm going
to say that it's also might be easy for these guys
to remember how much force.

They can always put
enough force on it. But when I was
doing some tests, I wasn't always getting
enough force on there.

And the people who are doing
this are women and girls, so it's--

even like 9, 10,
12-year-old girls, being able to latch
it down from having to hold all the pressure
there all the time.

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] last year. BUS LEONARD: No,
this is a new arm. We left the last year's model
in Nicaragua with AsoFenix.

And it works off
the 12 volt battery. I'm not sure if it's being
used in another community.

BRIANNA: It's not orange
juice season at the moment. So exactly, right now,
it's not being used.

I don't know whether
they will take it out to the community to use it
when it becomes orange-- BUS LEONARD: Last
year's project also

did not have the specification
to remove the air. So using that while removing
the air is also more difficult.

AUDIENCE: Feedback you have
is based on from the field or from your own-- BUS LEONARD: From the
field, from our spring

break trip down to
Nicaragua and fact finding there with in El Roblar.
With, yeah. AUDIENCE: You have any-- show pictures of that testing?

BUS LEONARD: Yeah,
we have pictures.  No, no, thank you.

AUDIENCE: One thing you
might want to think about is since you're trying to
create at least notionally

sterile stuff, you
might want to start--

it might be time to start
thinking about segregating this thing into the stuff
you have to keep clean in the stuff you don't
have to keep clean.

Because having to reach over
with your sterile hand that's

in all the juice
and all the stuff you're trying to be
clean, and reach over and hit the button on
the top of the timer

is going to become a drag
if that button somehow has to stay clean,
if you can give them things like foot pedals, and
elbow switches, and stuff.

So that just to think
about the process. And how you're going to
keep the clean stuff clean

and minimize the amount
of stuff you actually have to use sterile.

AUDIENCE: I probably
missed it, but what is the price point [INAUDIBLE].

BRIANNA: There aren't devices
that use low power like this. I'm not sure what the
price for the impulse is,

but running it off batteries
or the micro hydrogrid, you can't use that. It uses more power
than-- there's

a limit to the amount of power
that any device they've run off the micro hydrogrid that
AsoFenix has installed

is allowed to draw. BUS LEONARD: So
AsoFenix doesn't allow the use of irons, or hair
dryers, or hair straighteners,

or anything that's heavy
power intensive like that.

BRIANNA: When we compare what
we have to the design that was made last year, I think
we're probably about $10

less, which if you
don't include a battery, I think that makes us around $40
instead of around $50, which--

AUDIENCE: So it's
not [INAUDIBLE].. BRIANNA: No,
instead of sealing--

or instead of the
commercial ones that use a large amount of
power for about half a second,

this will use 30 watts
for more like 10 seconds.

BUS LEONARD: So
these are our photos working in the field in the
house we stayed in El Roblar.

A group of about 8 to 10 of
the women of the town came. And we gave a demonstration
of how it works.
Scroll through.

So this is-- we
found out that there were number 12 volt batteries. So we strung up a bunch
of AA and AAA batteries

just to be able to
do the demonstration. So that-- BRIANNA: We got like
somewhere between 6 and 10 bags of that
for the batteries.

BUS LEONARD: So
this is the process.

And they actually got to
seal a few bags themselves.

Let me if you have any questions
as we're going through.

AUDIENCE: Do you have any sense
about a minimally acceptable amount of air?

CARTER: We heard from
the community partners that they didn't want any air. So in terms of room for
air, we're not sure.

We don't know. AUDIENCE: Because
I wonder if there's a correlation between
the size of that bar that's hanging off
it and how much air.

Presumably, if you make
a really sharp edge. CARTER: So ideally, we're
going to have the nichrome wire as close to the edge
as possible to get

as clean a seal as possible. Because the more--
the further in it is,

the more overlap there is. So there's going to be
potentially more air. It's easier to get a--
clamp like this versus top one.

BUS LEONARD: And that's
actually the last photo. We tried to run it
off solar as well.

But this is getting away
from the presentation more. AUDIENCE: So how many bags
did you guys seal over

the course of this semester? BUS LEONARD: Oh,
including the testing, where we were just doing--

AUDIENCE: Five gallons
worth of orange juice, or five gallons worth
of water, and 100 bags.

CARTER: We usually just-- AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
[? responses, ?] or is it just [INAUDIBLE]? CARTER: Off every now and then.

We've been sealing bags the
size of at least 20 or so.

BUS LEONARD: But that was with
our kind of works like model. So we haven't
combined the sealer

with this ergonomic
application of it yet to have something that.

AUDIENCE: Are those bags-- individual bags largely
available in Nicaragua? Or do you get it on a long tube?

BUS LEONARD: You get
it on a long tube. And we have about six
feet of that tube here.

AUDIENCE: Have you
thought about how that would-- how
that could change the process a little bit? You could fill the whole
tube with orange juice.

CARTER: Seal, seal,
seal, and then just cut. BRIANNA: We have a long tube. And that's for the
individual size.

We aren't sure that
that would always be what they would get,
especially if they're like one or two liter bags.

So we wanted something-- I think we were trying to go
a little more flexible, rather than specifically for--

that would only be advantaged
with the long tube.

AUDIENCE: Still use that
process [INAUDIBLE].. AUDIENCE: Right, and if you
had a little extra add-on
to support [INAUDIBLE].

AUDIENCE: That's actually
something [INAUDIBLE]

all you have filled above
what your sealing another half of bag worth of orange juice. So you don't have to hold--

If you're filling
one liter bags, you don't want to have
to hold 50 pounds of bags above this thing.

But if you have it as
a continuous process, you've only got like
a 1/2 a bag's worth of stuff supported above, no
matter what size the bag is.

And then you keep filling it,
once you made that last seal, then it makes the support
problems a little bit easier.

You might want to start
thinking about that.

AUDIENCE: Does the-- once
the orange juice is sealed, does it need refrigeration?

As long as there's no air. BUS LEONARD:
Pasteurization process

that comes before, as
long as there's no air.

Is there a standard for size
of bubble that can remain? Or does it have to
be absolutely none?
CARTER: We're not sure.

PROFESSOR: You guys were
going to look into that. Any progress there? BRIANNA: I think I
think most answer we got

was there needs to be removed. There needs to be no air. And whether that's
overstating the requirement

or actually there
really actually needs to be no air, that's
where we're unsure, I think.

So we're making our goal be
there be actually no air. PROFESSOR: And you
started testing to see if you can
actually successfully

seal with zero air, or
zero noticeable air? BRIANNA: I think we did one with
our flat one that wasn't even
that we had no air in.

AUDIENCE: How crazy is there
pasteurization process? Put it in a pot, boil
it for 10 minutes,
and then put in the back? BUS LEONARD: Some citric acid.

AUDIENCE: I'll bet it
depends a lot more on keeping the clean room clean
than on air in the bag. Because there's air in the
bottle of Sunny Delight.

There's air at the top of-- there's air at the top
of the jar of pickles. It's pasteurized.

And it's highly acid. And you're trying to [INAUDIBLE]
to give them [INAUDIBLE]..

PROFESSOR: Well, it'd be good
to both be able to answer that and also know even if you have
the answer that air is OK,

if they are convinced
that air is not OK, that may be a knockout blow.

And so practicing to
make sure the ergonomics and whatever your
process are set up such

that you can actually ensure
that most of the time, you're getting a bag with no air
visible I think would be good
to practice that a bunch.

AUDIENCE: I heard you guys talk
about [INAUDIBLE] I'm not sure

I'm just wondering [INAUDIBLE]. BRIANNA: It probably wouldn't
be directly wood like that.

This was an earlier model. We've got it covered in
plastic, probably the way

we're going to go. Last year was
painted or lacquered.

So definitely be some kind of
more wipe-downable surface.

AUDIENCE: As long as it-- what kills wood is going
wet, dry, wet, dry, wet, dry over and over
again, like if you're

going to run it
all day long wet, it's not the end of the world.

You just might not want to
make it out of something-- it's nice to be able to
make the surface flat. So you can clean them.

So really soft [INAUDIBLE]
and harder stuff, but harder would
repel [INAUDIBLE]..

AUDIENCE: I think one
of their main concerns also was capturing
the overflow juice. In that case, you want
a very sterile surface.

And as clean as you can get. If you have an extra 8 inches
off your roll of plastic

or 6 inches off
your roll of plastic that you can just wrap that
bottom portion with it as kind of runoff.

Then you don't actually have to
worry about cleaning your wood as much as you would have.

BRIANNA: It's also
nice in the overflow to soak into the device
rather than being reclaimed.

AUDIENCE: Probably
the first [INAUDIBLE]..  PROFESSOR: OK, thanks, you guys.
[APPLAUSE]

VIVIAN: Hi, we're
the charcoal group. I'm Vivian. JESSICA: I'm Jessica. CURT: And I'm Curt.

VIVIAN: And our project
mentors are Amelia, raise your hand, and
Steve over there.
So first, our main--

sorry-- OK, our main
motivation for our project

stems from the work we
did with a Nicaraguan based NGO called GrupoFenix
and more specifically, we

worked with a cooperative called
the Mujeres Solares, which is the solar wind.

Basically, we
introduced the idea of D-Lab's agri-waste charcoal.

And for those of who
aren't familiar with it, it's basically a process
of making charcoal out

of agri-waste or
biomass, instead of wood. So you reduce deforestation.

And it burns a lot cleaner. We really wanted to
improve this process.

So that the women would
feel more comfortable integrating this into
their everyday lives, or possibly using this as a
business activity for them.

Right now, there is a general
discomfort with the process. And Jess can talk to
you a little bit more

about those specifics. JESSICA: So what was
really unique to our group was that we had the language
to get the direct feedback

from the women. So we didn't have to go
through a third person. Instead, I was able to interpret
exactly what they were saying.

And I have highlighted here
that the biggest issue for them

today is still
covering the barrel, because they cannot bathe
afterwards after dealing with

so much heat of the barrel. They say that the heat is
too intensive for them. And then would bathe
with cold water,

and then they would
get sick afterwards. So that's the biggest
gap for them right now. Even when we discussed the
different project ideas

that we had to make the
charcoal process better, they still brought
us back to we really

want you to work on
the barrel to something so that it doesn't feel so hot.

VIVIAN: So we're
going to show you a video of women
doing a charcoal burn.

JESSICA: Well, I
can't fast forward. This is the third charcoal
burn that the women are doing by themselves.

We trained them. And then we had them do the
first two by themselves. They were successful. This is the third one.

And you can see that
even in the third trial, there's still some
uncoordination

in the barrel sealing. This is a current
design, where the barrel sits on top of the bricks.

And you have to tilt and kick,
and sometimes kick too much. And so what we can see here are
the main points, the main pain

points of the
process, which are-- stop that right now, which
are the heat intensity

of the process, which is
what they've identified, and of course, the safety issue. And we realize that we
need to address these two

concerns while still meeting
the same quality of a charcoal burn. CURT: Great, so in order to meet
these criteria that Jess just

highlighted, our
design submerges the bricks on which the
barrel sits into the ground.

And so basically,
what we've done, here, I can show you
on our model here.

This is-- one of the
ideas of the charcoal burn is that it uses
commonly available materials,

like a oil drum. So I've used a Natty Ice can
here to, in the same spirit.

And so instead of sitting
on top of the ground, it now sits on bricks that
are submerged into holes.

And so the design
is pretty simple. There is a dugout whole.

There are six bricks that
line three channels which allow for airflow.

In this space right here,
the ground and the barrel form a seal.

So the barrel does not move
once it's been lit on fire.

And we've calculated
the airflow. So that there is sufficient
airflow through those channels

into the holes that are at
the bottom of the barrel. So that the-- while it's
burning, there's enough air.

And so to work on sealing
these channels, we have--

we've come up with these
metal plates right here. So essentially, this
is just sheet metal.

And it has these handles
on top, we call them. And they can be pushed
in underneath the--

over, rather, the three
channels to seal them. And just with a
little bit of sand,

it forms a seal around
the whole barrel. So eliminates the need
for tilting the barrel, kicking it, kicking out the
bricks, and all of that.

And we experimented
with a number of shapes here at the top. So this is semi-circular. We also have triangular
shapes, and then

various types of
handles, which Jessica we'll go into in a second. So an overview of the benefits
of this design compared

to the existing-- the existing portion
of the process that we're trying to
fit are first that it

minimizes the heat exposure. Because the flaming barrel
is now in the ground,

and there's no space
for the-- there's minimized space for
this heat to come out.

The second is that one person
can seal the barrel, rather

than needing two. And we can show video
of that right now.

Yeah, so this is
the entire process.

And I'll talk through this. Third is that you can
still light the barrel

through the channels. And the barrel doesn't move
once it's on fire and flaming.

So as you can see,
all Jessica is doing here is just pushing the
plates in at a safe distance

and with minimal exposure
to heat basically.

JESSICA: And so
from our experiment, we were able to conclude what
designs of sheet and handles

were better equipped to
meet our project attributes. We wanted to be able
to steer the sheet. And the better design for that
was the semi-circular plate.

In terms of
maneuvering and being precise about where
the sheet was going, the lipped handle, which
is this one right here,

allowed for the wood to come
in and kind of fit right there just enough to be able to
maneuver the sheet into where

we wanted it. The lifting
potential of the lift handle allowed us
to kick the sheet up

a little bit if it ever got
stuck right before the brick. And the three sheets
worked equally

as well to diminish
the heat exposure and to lessen the time that
it took to seal the barrel.

Now, stepping back for a second,
the sheet metal is only one of three sealing--

barrel sealing alternatives that
we're considering right now. The other two are
inserting a break

into the channel of the
dugout and covering the rest with sand. And the third is even
simpler than that,

just shoveling in or pouring
in sand into the three holes. And of course, on the left,
we have different design--

excuse me, specifications
that we want this to meet. Because it's part of the
process that before was most

heat intensive. You'll see, there's an
even spread right now of all the three designs.

For example, the sheet metal
is best in diminishing, or in lessening the time
that it takes to seal.

But the sand could be
done from farthest away. You just sort of take the sand
and throw it into the barrel,

throw it in along the side. But this is due to the
metrics of the attributes. For example, the
labor intensity,

we consider that it's

GUEST SPEAKER 1:
As we speak, we're actually going to pass
around the little Ziploc bags

of the experiments
we did with the rice. And the NGO that we worked
with was called ASAPROSAR.

And we are actually
part of the class that went to El Salvador
and not Nicaragua.

We worked in a community called
La Magdalena in El Salvador. And the NGO is currently
introducing rice cultivation

in the community both to be
used as a source of income and also as nutrition.

And in order for the rice
to be ready for consumption, it needs to be processed.

And the process involves
threshing and dehusking. And current methods of dehusking
are very time and money

intensive. They usually involve
a two to three hour bus ride to a mill where
the rice can be processed.

And it costs about $3
to $4, we found out, which is about a daily salary.

So our design challenge is
to develop a method that's-- for more local, faster, and
cheaper way of dehusking rice.

The two most important
project specifications that we focused on
were the efficiency,

which refers to
the amount of rice that's successfully
dehusked, and also how gentle the
process is, meaning

we wanted to minimize the amount
of rice that's broken or cut in half. And some of the other
specifications we looked at

were safety, affordability, of
course, durability, and also

aesthetics. We approached the
problem by brainstorming.

We researched some
existing technologies that people use in regions
that rice is grown.

Some of them are more simple. Some of them involve
heavy machinery. What we concluded, though, is
that all of these technologies

use friction in order to
get the husk from the rice. And it's a matter of adjusting
the amount of friction

we have in order to get the
husk off, but not break the rice grain. And some of the
ideas we ran through

were pepper grinder, where
we have cylinders rotating together, rubbing
together plates

that can be made from different
materials, mortar and pestle idea which is used, but it's
a lot more energy intensive

and not as efficient, and
also the molino, which is a corn mill that's
currently used in El Salvador

to grain corn. And that's basically
two circular plates that rub together.

And that's what we
actually have over there. GUEST SPEAKER 2: So
Amy Smith actually

had visited this
community before we had. And she had looked
at this molino and inserted a black inner tube
in between the two metal parts.

So we use that kind of
as our standard when we were looking
at how we could go about improving this process.

So we used this Pugh chart
with these attributes to figure out which one would
be the most feasible to do this

semester and which one
would be the most efficient for the community
to use overall.

In the end, we chose to
modify the existing molino by inserting a different
material in between the plates.

Right now, we have the two
leather inserts in there.

So we kind of just
add a circular insert in between them.

The advantages of
using the molino is that our community
partner, ASAPROSAR is actually

distributing the molinos to
the community to use for corn-- to make cornmeal,
to grind yucca, to--

and so it's very
multifunctional for them. And although the cost
is $20, ASAPROSAR is funding this distribution
to the communities.

And as it is now, either
one family will use it, or a whole community
will use it. So it's available
to a lot of people.

It's pretty durable. The metal is pretty rigid. And it's not labor intensive. It's just a hand
crank that you use.

A few of the challenges
with the molino, though, is that when you just
do it without any insert,

it cracks or breaks the rice. So people don't really
necessarily want broken rice.

And it wears the material down. If you put something
in there, we kind of need a durable material that
will withstand this turning.

So we decided upon five
different materials that we wanted to test. And we looked at leather,
rubber, metal, wood,

and fabric. And based on those, we looked at
the cost, residue, durability, and availability of those.

We brought back leather and
rubber from El Salvador, so we actually could
use stuff that was

available in those communities. And Lucy will talk to
you about what we found.
